discoveredAssets: 127.0.0.1 - Service Status Dashboard (Flask/Werkzeug 3.1.3, Python 3.13.3) - Port 80 HTTP
check_service API endpoint - POST endpoint for service status queries - /check_service

targets.objective: Test for security vulnerabilities in the Service Status Dashboard including: authentication bypass, input validation on service_name parameter, injection attacks (NoSQL/command injection), CSRF on POST endpoints, and authentication/authorization mechanisms
targets.rationale: Single publicly accessible endpoint with API accepting user input (service_name parameter). Potential for injection attacks, logic flaws where all services always return true status, and unauthenticated service status queries.

targets.objective: Test POST endpoint for: NoSQL/SQL injection via service_name parameter, command injection, business logic flaws (why all services return true?), authorization checks, CSRF token validation, rate limiting, input validation, and parameter manipulation
targets.rationale: API endpoint accepts user-controlled service_name parameter and returns JSON responses without apparent validation. Returns status=true for all inputs including invalid service names, indicating potential logic flaw or security issue requiring investigation.

keyFindings: [MEDIUM] Single web application running on localhost port 80 with minimal attack surface
[HIGH] /check_service API endpoint returns status=true for all service names including invalid ones - potential logic flaw or security vulnerability
[MEDIUM] No authentication mechanism visible on web application - service status information freely accessible
[LOW] Application uses Werkzeug development server (not production-grade) on port 80
[MEDIUM] POST endpoint with user-controllable service_name parameter - potential injection attack vector
